facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated July 5, 1954 of Punjab High Court in L.P.A. No. 29 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated July 5, 1954. of the Punjab High Court in L. P. A. No. 29 of 1953.

facts.text: Suit for possession of land brought by Munshi Ram, respondent.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment of the Punjab High Court and arises out of a suit for possession of land brought by Munshi Ram, respondent.

facts.text: Munshi Ram is the adopted son of Ata.

anchor.surface_text: Munshi Ram himself was adopted by Ata in 1918 before the death of his natural father Hans Raj

facts.text: Munshi Ram was adopted by Ata in 1918.

anchor.surface_text: Munshi Ram himself was adopted by Ata in 1918 before the death of his natural father Hans Raj which took place in 1920.

facts.text: Hans Raj, natural father of Munshi Ram, died in 1920.

anchor.surface_text: before the death of his natural father Hans Raj which took place in 1920.

facts.text: Nanak Chand died in 1939.

anchor.surface_text: Nanak Chand. Nanak Chand died in 1939. Munshi Rams natural father Hans Raj had predeceased Nanak Dhand.

facts.text: Hans Raj predeceased Nanak Chand.

anchor.surface_text: Munshi Rams natural father Hans Raj had predeceased Nanak Dhand. Munshi Ram himself was adopted by Ata in 1918

facts.text: Hans Raj never succeeded to the property of his father Nanak Chand.

anchor.surface_text: It will be clear from these dates therefore that Hans Raj never succeeded to the property of his father Nanak Chand

facts.text: Munshi Ram claimed entitled to one-half share of property left by Nanak Chand as his heir according to Zamindara custom.

anchor.surface_text: The case of Munshi Ram was that he was entitled to one-half share of the property left by Nanak Chand as his their, according to Zamindara custom.

facts.text: Parties are Brahmins.

anchor.surface_text: The parties, it may be Mentioned, are Brahmins and Munshi Ram claimed joint possession of the half share

facts.text: Salig Ram is the other son of Nanak Chand.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted by Salig Ram  defendant- appellant  who is the other son of Nanak Chand.

facts.text: Salig Ram claimed Munshi Ram not entitled to any share in Nanak Chand's property per personal law or riwaj-i-am of Amritsar district.

anchor.surface_text: His case was that Munshi Ram was number entitled either according to personal law or the riwaj-i-am of Amritsar district to any share in the property left by Nanak Chand.

facts.text: Trial court held Munshi Ram entitled to succeed to Nanak Chand's property along with Salig Ram and decreed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt held that Munshi Ram was entitled to succeed to the property left. by, Nanak Chand along with Salig Ram and decreed the suit accordingly

facts.text: Salig Ram appealed to District Judge but failed.

anchor.surface_text: Salig Ram went in appeal to the District Judge but failed. He then went in second appeal to the High Court

facts.text: Salig Ram's second appeal to High Court was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: He then went in second appeal to the High Court but the second appeal was also dismissed

facts.text: High Court refused certificate; appellant applied to Supreme Court for special leave which was granted.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having refused to grant a certificate the appellant applied to this Court for special leave which was granted and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: No dispute about property of Santu.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute number about the property of Santu and we are companycerned in this appeal only with the property of Nanak Chand.

facts.text: Appeal concerned only with property of Nanak Chand.

anchor.surface_text: and we are companycerned in this appeal only with the property of Nanak Chand. Nanak Chand died in 1939.

facts.text: Nanak Chand is natural grandfather of Munshi Ram.

anchor.surface_text: The claim of Munshi Ram was with respect to the property left by Nanak Chand who is his natural grandfather and also Santu.

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment on March 21, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This is an appeal

facts.text: Munshi Ram claimed adoption by Ata according to custom during lifetime of Hans Raj.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated July 5, 1954. of the Punjab High Court in L. P. A. No. 29 of 1953.

In questions regarding succession and certain other matters, the law in the Punjab is contained in s. 5 of the Punjab Laws Act, No. IV of 1872. Clause b of that section provides that the rule of decision in such matters shall be the Hindu law where the parties are Hindus, except in so far as such law has been altered or abolished by legislative enactment, or is opposed to the provisions of this Act or has been modified by any such custom as is referred to in cl. a thereof. Clause a provides that any custom applicable to the parties concerned, which is not contrary to Justice, equity or good conscience, and has not been by this or any other enactment altered or abolished and has not been declared to be void by any competent authority shall be applied in such matters.

concepts.interpretation: Hindu law applies first to Hindus in succession matters; custom at variance must be proved by the asserting party; custom applies if not contrary to justice, equity, good conscience.

anchor.surface_text: However, the custom that is relied upon is to be found in para. 48 of the Digest of Customary Law in the Punjab by Rattigan at p. 572, 13th Edition. This paragraph appears in section V dealing with Effect of Adoption on Succession and is in the following terms- An heir appointed in the manner above described ordinarily does not thereby lose his right to succeed to property in his natural family, as against collaterals, but does not succeed in the presence of his natural brothers.

concepts.interpretation: Adopted son retains succession rights in natural family against collaterals but not in presence of natural brothers; applied but held inapplicable here due to brother's presence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets s.5 Punjab Laws Act: Hindu law prima facie; burden on party asserting variant custom; cites Robertson J., Privy Council, Supreme Court precedents.

holdings.text: Munshi Ram having been adopted by Ata would have no right left in the family of his natural father Hans Raj, unless the adoption was in the dvyamushyayana form.

anchor.surface_text: Thus Munshi Ram having been adopted by Ata would have no right left in the family of his natural father Hans Raj, unless the adoption was in the dvyamushyayana form. It was however never the case of Munshi Ram that the adoption was in dvyamushyayana form and so far as Hindu law is concerned, if it applies to this case Munshi Ram would not be entitled after the adoption to succeed to the property left by Nanak Chand.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Hindu law on adoption severing natural family rights absent special dvyamushyayana form; no claim of such form by plaintiff.

holdings.text: amongst Brahmins and Khatris of Amritsar district, a son given away in adoption can succeed to the property of his natural father only if there is no other son of the natural father if there is another son he cannot succeed.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion therefore at which we arrive is that amongst Brahmins and Khatris of Amritsar district, a son given away in adoption can succeed to the property of his natural father only if there is no other son of the natural father if there is another son he cannot succeed. Now let us see how this proposition works out in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analyzes riwaj-i-am entries (1865,1911-12,1940); reconciles confusion; determines specific custom for Brahmins/Khatris excluding adopted son if brother exists.

holdings.text: there is therefore an initial presumption of correctness as regards the entries in the Riwaj-i-am and when the custom as recorded in the Riwaj-i-am is in conflict with the general custom as recorded in Rattigans Digest or ascertained otherwise, the entries in the Riwaj-i-am should ordinarily prevail

Sher Singh and others, where this Court held that- there is therefore an initial presumption of correctness as regards the entries in the Riwaj-i-am and when the custom as recorded in the Riwaj-i-am is in conflict with the general custom as recorded in Rattigans Digest or ascertained otherwise, the entries in the Riwaj-i-am should ordinarily prevail except that as was pointed out by the Judicial Committee of the, Privy Council

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites own precedent Jai Kaur; presumption stronger absent female rights impact; local riwaj-i-am prevails over general Rattigan para 48.

holdings.text: if Munshi Ram is to succeed by the application of the principle of representation it would follow that Munshi Ram would really be deemed to be Hans Raj at the time of the death of Nanak Chand. In that case the position would be that Nanak Chand would have died leaving two sons, namely, Salig Ram and Munshi Ram in the guise of Hans Raj. But Munshi Ram having been adopted away and there being another son of Nanak Chand, even the custom recorded in para. 48 would exclude Munshi Ram

anchor.surface_text: But if Munshi Ram is to succeed by the application of the principle of representation it would follow that Munshi Ram would really be deemed to be Hans Raj at the time of the death of Nanak Chand. In that case the position would be that Nanak Chand would have died leaving two sons, namely, Salig Ram and Munshi Ram in the guise of Hans Raj. But Munshi Ram having been adopted away and there being another son of Nanak Chand, even the custom recorded in para. 48 would exclude Munshi Ram because then there would be a brother of Munshi Ram alive in the family of Nanak Chand and this brother would succeed in exclusion of Munshi Ram who would be representing his father.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects partial application of representation; full deeming treats plaintiff as adopted Hans Raj with living brother Salig Ram, excluding under para 48 and local custom.

holdings.text: neither under Hindu law nor under the custom recorded in para. 48 can Munshi Ram succeed to the property of Nanak Chand.

anchor.surface_text: The position therefore is that neither under Hindu law nor under the custom recorded in para. 48 can Munshi Ram succeed to the property of Nanak Chand. We therefore allow the appeal and set aside the decree of the courts below and dismiss the suit of the plaintiff-respondent so far as the property of Nanak Chand is concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Culminating application: no entitlement under either Hindu law or applicable custom (general or local); allows appeal, dismisses suit.

holdings.text: the entries in the riwaj-i-am of Amritsar district in 1865, if they conflict with para. 48 of Rattigans Digest,, should prevail.

anchor.surface_text: As females are not concerned in this case, the entries in the riwaj-i-am of Amritsar district in 1865, if they conflict with para. 48 of Rattigans Digest,, should prevail. On that view Munshi Ram would have no right to succeed in the family of his natural father after he was adopted by Ata.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Jai Kaur presumption; no female rights affected, so local custom prevails over general.

There is no presumption created by the clause in favour of custom.

anchor.surface_text: The position therefore that emerges is, where the parties are Hindus, the Hindu law would apply in the first instance and whosoever asserts a custom at variance with the Hindu law shall have to prove it, though the quantum of proof required in support of the custom which is general and well recognised may be small while in other cases of what are called special customs the quantum may be larger.

edges.explanation: Holding states the adoption custom among Amritsar Brahmins/Khatris excluding adopted son if other sons exist, supporting riwaj-i-am custom concept

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion therefore at which we arrive is that amongst Brahmins and Khatris of Amritsar district, a son given away in adoption can succeed to the property of his natural father only if there is no other son of the natural father if there is another son he cannot succeed. Now let us see how this proposition works out in the present case.

edges.explanation: Holding undercuts full application of the principle by noting it would deem Munshi Ram as Hans Raj at Nanak Chand's death, leading to inconsistency.

anchor.surface_text: Chand. In that case the position would be that Nanak Chand would have died leaving two sons, namely, Salig Ram and Munshi Ram in the guise of Hans Ra

edges.explanation: Holding addresses the issue by examining implications of succession under the principle of representation.

anchor.surface_text: But if Munshi Ram is to succeed by the application of the principle of representation it would follow that Munshi Ram would really be deemed to be Hans Raj at the time of the death of Nanak Chand. In that case the position would be that Nanak Chand would have died leaving two sons, namely, Salig Ram and Munshi Ram in the guise of Hans Raj. But Munshi Ram having been adopted away and there being another son of Nanak Chand, even the custom recorded in para. 48 would exclude Munshi Ram because then there would be a brother of Munshi Ram alive in the family of Nanak Chand and this brother would succeed in exclusion of Munshi Ram who would be representing his father.
We therefore allow the appeal and set aside the decree of the companyrts below and dismiss the suit of the plaintiff-respondent so far as the property of Nanak Chand is companycerned.
We therefore allow the appeal and set aside the decree of the companyrts below and dismiss the suit of the plaintiff-respondent so far as the property of Nanak Chand is companycerned.

edges.explanation: Holding that riwaj-i-am entries prevail over Rattigan supports the concept that riwaj-i-am governs

anchor.surface_text: As females are not concerned in this case, the entries in the riwaj-i-am of Amritsar district in 1865, if they conflict with para. 48 of Rattigans Digest,, should prevail. On that view Munshi Ram would have no right to succeed in the family of his natural father after he was adopted by Ata.
We therefore allow the appeal and set aside the decree of the companyrts below and dismiss the suit of the plaintiff-respondent so far as the property of Nanak Chand is companycerned.
